skills.name: Zend
skills.tooltip: Done few sites in 1.X. Not my favourite, but I know it well.

skills.name: Kohana
skills.tooltip: This one used to be a monster. Can fix it for you, but won't recommend it.

skills.name: CodeIgniter
skills.tooltip: Did some discovery and was quite satisfied with, went for the Laravel instead.

skills.name: Laravel
skills.tooltip: Framework with very thoughtful architectural design which can be compared to Python's Django or Perl's Catalyst

skills.name: Java
skills.tooltip: Did some personal projects and small GUI tools for use with business. I also know Java Security.

skills.name: C#
skills.tooltip: Mostly for security-based projects - strictly academic experience.

skills.name: JavaScript
skills.tooltip: Prototype, jQuery even raw AJAX queries and such

skills.name: CoffeeScript
skills.tooltip: Cleaner JavaScript, I use it when I'm not constrained to pure JavaScript

skills.name: HTML5
skills.tooltip: Like SVG, Canvas and stuff, along with Raphael.JS, Kinetic.JS, Paper.js

skills.name: CSS/SASS
skills.tooltip: I know how it works and I can use it well. I'm not a cross-browser-warrior (but I do know someone who is if that counts)

skills.name: CSS Frameworks
skills.tooltip: Such as HTML5Boilerplate, Twitter Bootstrap and Foundation - been there, seen them, didn't get a t-shirt :(

skills.name: Angular.js
skills.tooltip: MVVM/MVC library by Google. Trivia: this site was made with Angular.js

skills.name: Knockout.js
skills.tooltip: MVVM library. Learned it before moving on into Angular.js, it's still a great solution though.

skills.name: Node.js
skills.tooltip: While it's not 'pure' frontend library it's a part of frontend stack, which I use

skills.name: jQuery
skills.tooltip: Done plenty work with it, even wrote a plugin once or twice.

skills.name: HTML
skills.tooltip: Not only as a variant of XML, but also with knowledge how to create well formed HTML (i.e. don't nest div's in span's and stuff)

skills.name: XML
skills.tooltip: Reading through SAX and DOM, transforming huge amounts of data, mapping, queries using XPATH. There are no XML secrets for me.

skills.name: JSON
skills.tooltip: Serialized not once, not twice. Wan't to see something neat? Go to /jsons/skills.json. And yes - I've typed it!

skills.name: Python
skills.tooltip: Done web apps, tools etc. Once upon a time I developed package manager using Python, but that was long time ago

skills.name: Ruby
skills.tooltip: Beside doing some development for Redmine (RoR) I also implemented SBQL in Ruby as a part of my Master thesis using reflective features of Ruby

skills.name: PHP
skills.tooltip: If it's PHP it cannot hide from me. Half time of my last 5 years included working with PHP.

skills.name: Perl 5
skills.tooltip: Done some small tools and live e-mail parser and rewriter - and it worked well

skills.name: SQL
skills.tooltip: I am expert in constructing complex queries and optimizing them.

skills.name: MySQL
skills.tooltip: Beside SQL I also know database engine quirks for MySQL.

skills.name: PostgreSQL
skills.tooltip: I optimized database, tuned profilers and even wrote my own b-tree and hashed indexes.

skills.name: SQlite
skills.tooltip: I know how to handle it but it gives me creeps.

skills.name: Linux
skills.tooltip: My commercial experience includes setting up Debian and CentOS on bunch of machines. On desktop I used Fedora, Ubuntu and (long time ago) Arch, Gentoo and LFS

skills.name: Apache
skills.tooltip: I've set up dozens of those along with memory configuration, optimization etc.

skills.name: Databases
skills.tooltip: I know configuration quirks, server side optimization and did some really crazy stuff like master-master replication

skills.name: Clustering
skills.tooltip: It's something like cloud, but I knew on which server my software worked on

skills.name: Monitoring
skills.tooltip: Deployed Munin, Zabbix and custom monitoring solutions. Tried Nagios, but didn't like it.

skills.name: ERD
skills.tooltip: When setting up a new app I often design it beforehand using ERD

skills.name: UML
skills.tooltip: Even though I rarely needed it, it helps me during design works

skills.name: ORM
skills.tooltip: ORM like in Object Role Modelling - design technique based on existing data - helps in conceptual modelling - used it for requirements discovery

skills.name: BPMN
skills.tooltip: It served me well for discussions with clients, in my opinion it is cleaner than flowcharts.

skills.name: MQ
skills.tooltip: I really like the concept, but had only single chance to deploy it and did so using RabbitMQ

skills.name: VIM
skills.tooltip: I am bearer of VIM curse - no other editor satisfies my anymore

skills.name: Brunch
skills.tooltip: HTML5 stack tool, which help building websites.

skills.name: Git/Hg/SVN
skills.tooltip: I worked with each of this systems. Currently my VC of choice is Git. Also I had setup central repositories for Mercurial and SVN.

skills.name: Erlang
skills.tooltip: Learned since I wanted to try different programming paradigm. Unfortunatelly I have absolutely nothing I could do in Erlang

skills.name: Prolog
skills.tooltip: Hated it when learned it, loved it when returned to it. Great for solving logic puzzles and some quite specialized solutions.

skills.name: Brainf*ck
skills.tooltip: Inspired by the name, it's nice puzzle-language. It broadens horizonts.

skills.name: Ook!
skills.tooltip: Very similar to Brainf*ck, but I had always Discworld feeling when using it

skills.name: LOLCode
skills.tooltip: I laugh everytime I read the docs.
